Description:
Hello,
in trying to apply Jacques Mahe's paper "CSI capture software data path" to our

project, I modified the kdgui_2dmgr sample from the 23.0017 PDK. In the

TwoDMgrRenderFrame function, I'm basically only calling the

kdWindowBindEGLImageNV function for two different KDWindow objects which are

bound to two different hardware layers. No actual GL call is done anymore, no

shader used, no plane rendered.



The layers are blended in hardware, but that's about everything that works until

now. We're facing several severe problems:



1. Despite only calling kdWindowBindEGLImageNV twice, the frame rate is at

   approximately 30 fps when the LVDS capture is active. This is the same result

   we measured when copying the textures and blending them via a shader!



2. The blended image contains heavy artifacts that resemble those typically

   observed when z-fighting occurs.



Our assumption is: Now that we're not doing a call to eglSwapBuffers anymore (as

we're not doing any GL calls), the two calls to kdWindowBindEGLImageNV are not

in sync with the graphic card's refresh rate.



If you don't think that's the case, please give us some more ideas what could be

going wrong. If you agree to our assumption: How would one synchronize the two

KDWindow objects / hardware layers while still using kdWindowBindEGLImageNV?



I'm attaching a video demonstrating the above mentioned problems. You'll see the

HMI, first with a static background image, then with LVDS capturing active

(black and white test image) and finally with another static background.



You'll notice that the fps drops to around 30 fps while the LVDS capture is

active. During the whole video, you'll see the above mentioned artifacts at the

bases of the needles and (more seldom) on the status bar area.



Kind regards,
Timo Schmiade

Description:
No SPI-NOR support with T124. So we need only focus on mNAND ...

===
Audi requires data to make a decision whether to boot from mnand or from NOR.

There is only a Quad-SPI NOR flash on K1 and no external bus interface, AFAIK.

Therefore makes not much sense to compare current NOR-performance on MIB2.
To verify boot-performance, goal is to benchmark current IFS size of stage 1+stage2+splash-screen equals 3+42+1.5=46.5MB. These are probably all sequential read operations.

If the boot-partition requires a lot of time, then we need to measure this value as well.

Please make a benchmark to compare:
A) read from Q-SPI NOR.
B) read from mnand (16nm? or latest) SLC area
C) read from mnand (16nm? or latest) MLC area

The results may be obtained by a Linux-OS, as long as these results are closely valid for QNX, this is fine.

Thanks.

Matthijs

Office +1-408-486-8034
Cell +1-650-391-4917
mailto:matthijs.paffen@audi.de or
mailto:matthijs.paffen@audi.com

Description:
In the A5 T210 TRM, I am looking for information on how to enable I2C6 (in the DP block) to be able to access the audio code, etc. on Google's A44/T210 (Smaug) board.



On A44/T132 (Ryu), this was done with SOR Power Gating to enable access to the DPAUX registers, then the I2C6_SDI/SCL RCVs were enabled and mode set to I2C in DPAUX_HYBRID_PADCTL register, 0x545C0124.



No DPAUX registers appear in the T210 spec, nor any explanation of how to enable I2C6 (we came up with a procedure/flow empirically (and painfully) on T132, and had it added to the T132 TRM - I was hoping it would be carried over for T210).



This will be blocking checkout of Audio on A44/T210 Smaug very soon.
Synopsis: T210: No DPAUX register info, needed for I2C6 enable

Description:
400.400.Even for preformatted text, I find that nvbugs deletes a single space from every sequence of 2+ spaces.  Is this intentional?



When I have tables that I wish to insert into testgen, I have to precompensate by inserting a space wherever I have 2+ spaces, so that when nvbugs does its delete, the table is in its original form.



You can see an example of such a table at http://nvbugs/200092654/3

Description:
Witcher 3 was released to the public before the Shield onboarding team was able to complete the onboarding process.

Due to this, the GameStream had to scramble to react to negative feedback.  We were a bit lucky for Witcher 3 since there was a GS release around the same time so that we could push changes out.

Looking forward, if there is a big title on the horizon, the onboarding process and the priority assigned for onboarding should be on-par with the nvidia driver team.

The nvidia driver team was able to push out a game ready driver for Witcher 3.  GameStream should ideally have been ready, just like them.
Synopsis: RFE: Shield onboarding should get the same priority and same visibility as 'game ready drivers' for big launches

Description:
For the new 4/6 class shared GPU ballout, we need to determine if we will ever want to support a differential strobe on future 4-6 Class parts.  Eliminating the need (i.e only balling out 1 S/E DQS) will improve SI (i.e more GND) and potentially increase our max G5/G5x speeds.

For Pascal, LPDDR4 is ONLY POR for 7-8 class, so the question is really targeting GV204-6 and future chip generations. Not only for LPDDR4, but also SDDRx & LPDDR5 in case they will require a differential strobe (spec development in progress now so pin list is not frozen).

I'm opening a bug based on feedback from last week's DRAM road map meeting to help drive this to closure.  Apologies in advance if this is not the right module.  Also please add anyone whom I may have missed.
Synopsis: Differential DQS support for Future 4-6 Class Parts

Description:
Test NAMD 2.10 with stream-out patch full profile for various single node systems and for various cluster systems. Summary NAMD 2.10 with stream-out patch full profile, was tested on single node systems for the following devices, K40’s, K80’s, M6000’s and 7120P’s. Single node systems were run on both Ivybridge and Haswell machines. NAMD 2.10 was also tested on the Ivybridge cluster with different configurations of K40’s, K80’s and CPU sockets enabled. Tests were run with both CUDA 6.5 and CUDA 7.0. Good
  • Single Node M6000’s, with both CUDA versions, running on Ivybridge systems outperformed 7120P’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node K80’s, with both CUDA versions, running on Ivybridge systems outperformed 7120P’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node M6000’s, with both CUDA versions, outperformed tests run on Ivybridge CPU’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node K80’s, with both CUDA versions, outperformed tests on Ivybridge CPU’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node M6000’s, with both CUDA versions, outperformed tests run on Haswell CPU’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node K80’s, with both CUDA versions, outperformed tests run on Haswell CPU’s, winning 100% of the tests
  • Single Node Systems show increased performance across the board as more GPU’s and CPU’s are added.
  • The K40’s on 1,2,4 and 8 nodes, with both CUDA versions, outperform tests on Ivybridge CPU’s on 1,2,4 and 8 nodes, winning 100% of the tests
  • The K80’s on 1,2 and 4 nodes, with both CUDA versions, outperform tests on Ivybridge CPU’s on 1,2 and 4 nodes, winning 100% of the tests
  • Increasing the number of nodes shows consistent performance increase across the board for both K40’s and K80’s
Validation ARB Nikolai Sakharnykh
Synopsis: Validation of pbr 133053 - NAMD 2.10 with stream-out patch full profile
Need some changes on how we look at variables in the query cache

Description:
For the first time, we are releasing the GL driver as a static library. The object files within the static library will contain internal symbol names, which are normally completely eliminated as part of the shared library linking stage. With a static lib release we do partial linking instead, and partial linking does not eliminate internal symbols [1].

I have modified the Odin packaging scripts to mangle the internal symbols as part of the release build. But we need to set up sufficient guardword checks that validate that all sensitive information is properly scrambled from the release binary.

This bug is about adding guardword checks to the Odin release build (or more precisely, to the packaging step of the release build, to $TEGRA_TOP/odin/scripts/Makefile).

Instructions to build libnvn.a: https://wiki.nvidia.com/odin/index.php/Building_Drivers_for_Horizon (use "release external" in the "choose" command).

[1] If you try to strip the internal symbols from the partially linked object manually using objcopy --strip-symbols, you'll get this error:
armv7l-rynda-horizon-eabihf-objcopy: not stripping symbol `_nvn000148' because it is named in a relocation
Synopsis: [Odin] Guardword checking for libnvn.a

Description: Source: GeForce Forums https://forums.geforce.com/default/topic/834157/geforce-drivers/announcing-hotfix-driver-353-00/post/4537961/#4537961 Maybe related to NVBug 1618806. An end user is reporting that with any driver after 344.75, his GPUs will throttle in SLI mode. No repro if SLI mode is disabled. Happens stock without overclocking or adjusting the voltage of the GPU or modifying the VBIOS. Occurs even with the latest 353.06 driver which has a fix for NVBug 1618806. User has a Alienware M18x R2 w/ | GTX 780M SLI https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zkqOfN0AQ7k&feature=youtu.be "Still a crap driver for GTX 780M SLI. Massive throttling and horrible FPS with moderate overclock. Didn't bother testing stock since stock is unimportant if overclocking is throttled. Don't care if DSR works if it throttles. Testing with 980M SLI on my Clevo P570WM sometime tomorrow. Hopefully, it will work correctly on at least one of my 4 beast laptops. The other three have GTX 780M. Edit: FOR THE RECORD, it does not throttle at stock clocks. So, behavior is same as 350.12 and 352.86 and throttles like a son of a ***** overclocked. Worthless driver. Don't care about DSR if I cannot overclock." "Actually, it is absolutely occurring because of the driver. The behavior only occurs with my 780M cards using newer drivers. If this was occurring due to ACPI throttling the behavior would be the same with all drivers. I own both Alienware and Clevo. In this case my Clevo with 980M SLI is working fine. It's only the Alienware 780M systems that are having issues, and it's only with the drivers since the release of 350.12 that my 780M cards don't work correctly. I have tested with ACPI enabled and disabled in the BIOS and it makes no difference, but it does seem directly related to power draw. It's like these cancer drivers are telling my system to slow down to reduce power consumption, and that really sucks. The drivers should not be influencing system behavior in this manner. Whatever they did to help my Maxwell GPUs work well seems to have come at the cost of Kepler stability. When I was trying to use these 980M cards (currently in my Clevo) in my M18xR2, they misbehaved in exactly the same manner as my 780M cards are misbehaving now with newer drivers. I never had these problems with 780M before, so it is clearly some kind of nasty cancer they have added to their drivers. Display drivers should ignore power draw, mind their own business, and leave system behavior up to the motherboard and AC adapter. Here's how this driver works with my Clevo... 3DMark 11: http://www.3dmark.com/3dm11/9849353 Image And, the Clevo was working fine with the drivers before this one... 3DMark 11: http://www.3dmark.com/3dm11/9463141 Image Fire Strike: http://www.3dmark.com/fs/4903861 Image"
Synopsis: EU/OEM, 353.06: GeForce 780M in SLI throttles when running 3d apps.  No repro on 344.75

Description: Add screenshot functionality based on glReadPixels() to nvgldemo. This has two advantages: 1. It is portable across all platforms. (Relying on the QNX screenshot functionality is not portable.) 2. There is no need to halt! Just create a commandline option like "-screenshot 20" to capture frame number 20 to a file. Original Bug Synopsis: add option to nvgldemo to halt on specified frame count... Description as discussed offline with Nate, add option to nvgldemo to halt on specified frame count... to get more testing in automation (i.e. bug 200105052), QNX SQA team would like to take advantage of the QNX ../bsp/install/armle-v7/usr/bin/screenshot utility to capture and compare display frames of various apps against golden images. We’d like to start with some of our simpler OGL apps (bubble/ctree/gears).... per Nate "My initial reaction is that if you want screenshots, build some screenshot functionality based on glReadPixels() instead of the QNX screenshot – this way the functionality works across all platforms, not just QNX". So if someone wants to repurpose this bug to make it generic so that it works with all demo's, apps, etc., that would be even better but again taking baby steps with just nvgldemo apps...
Synopsis: V3Q Audi_MMXF: Add option to nvgldemo to capture and save screen shot at given framecount

Description:
http://jirasw.nvidia.com/browse/MGT-157

I think it's time to create a manifest and start using repo tools for the mobile-graphics repos (similar to what dev-process has for the test harness repos).  Now that we have more git repos (with changes incoming on a regular basis), it would be immensely helpful to be able to use repo init/sync/etc to manage the tools codebase as a whole instead of having to deal with all of the git repos individually.  (For example, I can't even remember what some of the repos are called, and I don't think I have some of the new repos sync'd (and there's no easy way to find out which ones I'm missing).)
Synopsis: Create repo manifest for mobile-graphics tools repos

Description:
a) To be sure of correctness of our backprop code let's add gradient checkers for all layers.



http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Gradient_checking_and_advanced_optimization

We might have to use a higher order approximation such as 5-point stencil so we can get high enough precision for correctness.



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-point_stencil

For simple layers that don't involve long summations (such as activations) I believe we should be able to get correctness within at most 10*ULP(1.) for any given precision and inputs randomized as white noise of magnitude 1. So for doubles we should be able to get 1e-14, for singles 1e-6, for half 5e-3. If we run into obstacles like high derivatives or inexact implementations of math functions we should be able to implement higher accuracy functions via Taylor expansion etc. I feel like this work would be worth it to get our tolerances up to expected levels.



One implementation strategy is we could seed the tests with correctness for doubles first and then verify correctness of single and half1 vs already tested double implementation (treat the double implementation as infinite precision for single/half)



There is a gradient checker for DivisiveNormalization and BN layers, which could be used as an implementation example. There's also an implementation in Caffe.

b) Another suggested improvement is that we use RAND12 generator instead of the current slowly incrementing value generator which has potential to hide bugs due to zero second order deltas and potentially insufficient value delta coverage.



c) Another improvement would be to change all reference code to use doubles. This applies to both fwd and bwd layers.



d) Note that the error bound for both the gradient checker and the regular CPU vs CUDA tests is HIGHLY dependent on the filter size and in case of layers that do summation over a large input area, on the total number of sum terms.

Test should take this into account since the bound can vary greatly in the worst case scenario compared to average/typical case. It is not a good approach to set one epsilon to suit the worst case scenario since it effectively renders the entire test much less useful.
Synopsis: Improve test coverage - gradient checkers, half1 cross-precision validation, uniform random input coverage for all layers

Description:

2. The crash happens regardless if the debug layer is present or not, and there is no debug layer output.

We have attached a crash dump from this crash. If this dump is not sufficient, we can investigate remote debugging.

Description:
User measured higher latency with Gamestream compared to Moonlight (Limelight).

https://forums.geforce.com/default/topic/837825/shield-android-tv/nvidia-gamestream-and-moonlight-latency-test-wired-and-wireless-/

=====================================

Hello, I am an avid PC gamer and the main reason I purchased the shield console was to do gamestream. Sometimes it is just more comfortable laying on the couch playing instead of a computer desk. So one of my main goals was to test the latency for game stream using the shield console.

So for my setup I have 4670k OC, GTX 980, all wired to a ASUS RT-AC68U. For my shield console I tested gigabit Ethernet and I tested wifi on 5Ghz. I used Shadow of Mordor for my tests. My gamestream and moonlight settings were 1080 60FPS

The method I used to test the latency was a couple of items. First I used my sony xperia Z2 to record in 120FPS mode. In the recording I had the TV in the background, also the shield controller, and also a stopwatch.

I tested by starting the 120fps recording, started the stopwatch and then moved the right thumbstick from the center of the controller to the right side, back to center, then to the left side, back to center, and then back to the right side. So in total I had 3 data points per test.

Once I got all of the recordings I opened them up in VLC media player and went frame by frame to see the stopwatch time from when my thumb moved to when the tv screen in the background moved.

Here are the results

Wired Gamestream
Center to right: 250ms
Center to left: 310ms
Center to right: 370ms
AVG: 310ms

Wireless Gamestream
Center to right: 390ms
Center to left: 340ms
Center to right: 310ms
AVG: 340ms

Wireless Moonlight (Limelight)
Center to right: 260ms
Center to left: 340ms
Center to right: 250ms
AVG: 280ms

Wired Moonlight (Limelight)
Center to right: 320ms
Center to left: 270ms
Center to right: 320ms
AVG: 300ms

So in my experience with my network I average about 300ms from when i press a button to when something happens on screen. In my opinion games and playable at these latencys but I probably would stay away from fast pace games like call of duty.
=====================================

System Information:
Asrock Motherboard
Intel 4670k OC to 4.0 Ghz
8GB ram
250 GB SSD
EVGA GeForce GTX 980
RT-AC68U router (connected to PC via wired)
Windows 8.1 pro, Geforce experience 2.4.5.28 and driver 352.86
Sony KDL-70R550A ( When I did my tests I was in auto mode. I went back the next day and used game mode and that brought my latency average to 250ms instead of 300ms.)
Synopsis: EU/OEM-GAMESTREAM: Higher average latency with Gamestream compared with Moonlight (Limelight).

Description: While it's possible to store imagery on the Jetson, it is not yet possible to transfer full live imagery off the Jetson, due to no suitable interface. On the Jetson, the best options are the GigE port on the breakout board, and the USB 3.0 port. However, the GigE port is currently transmitting at only 1/4 rate (Lorna's working on improving that) and the USB port can at best only be used with the USB to GigE adapter, which will give only about half the bandwidth needed. One possible solution would be to convert the USB 3.0 port to be a device port, though this may require some development on the NVIDIA's part to support that. One thing that would help immensely is if it were possible to configure that cameras to transmit raw Bayer pattern imagery instead of YUV, as this data is only half as large. Conceivably, this could be fully routed through a single GigE connection, maybe being more feasible if the frame rate is dropped to 24 Hz instead of 30 Hz. [EDIT] Frame rate change tracked in bug 1648899 On the Drive PX, there are two USB 3.0 ports, one for each Tegra. Using converters to GigE, it seems like if each Tegra handles half the frames (or if two cameras are connected to each of two aggregators), that this might barely fit in the bandwidth. Whether such a data rate is achievable is something which NVIDIA should test. Again, things would be much more manageable if we were working with RAW data instead of YUV data.
Synopsis: [PreSales][VW/ERL]Need a solution to transfer full live imagery off of a Jetson and Drive PX

Description:
http://jirasw/browse/MGT-163

Currently, sanity alerts scan VRL for failing jobs on automatic builds, and then provide the option for email alerts with optional regex match.

This is a request for a pair of tools to provide expanded functionality - regex matching and email alerts on specified branch/gpu/testplan/etc configs for non-failure jobs.  The two tools are:
1)  A standalone tool (non cron) which may be invoked to scan the most recent N jobs matching the specified config for the specified regex (for one-off usage for specific cases)
2)  Ongoing scanning and periodic email alerts for matching jobs (just like existing sanity alerts, but for non-failure jobs).

This will solve several problem whereby we need to watch for specific results, or find out when a given behavior originated.  For example:

- Failures in staged tests (tests staged due to intermittent or non-WAR-able failures; need to find out if the failures are still happening)
- Certain known failures in ap_opengles (e.g. bug fixed, but image is gilded as a known failure - we need to see if the failure is still observed as the fix is delivered across branches.
- A given test result in graphics_submit changed from X to Y - need to trace the job where Y was first observed.

One challenge for the implementation is load on VRL.  We can't slam the VRL db with huge requests and downloads of hundreds of log files all at once.  I'd suggest a throttled approach - for example, query all jobs matching the specified config, then download one log every N seconds until we have them all.  This tool is not as time-sensitive as failure alerts, so it's ok for alert emails to be sent an hour or two after the fact, and (for the standalone tool) it's ok to make the user wait minutes (or hours) for their data processing to complete (i.e. instead of a real-time result in their browser, have the UI trigger a processing job, then email the user once their results are ready.)

We should also check with SWIO to see if functionality like this already exists.

...

One more use case, from Antoine:
- Find whether the kernel leak tolerance of 6 leaks currently assigned to graphics_submit is too high
Synopsis: Sanity alerts for non-failures

Description:
Currently PaymentActivity is clearing the back stack and restarting a new task on the LBGridWallAndErrorActivity. This is considered as Hijacking of the task and  its back stack since the LBGridFragment is expecting a result from Starting the LBGridWallAndErrorActivity with StartActivityForResult.



The assumption is that in an effort to complete this work in the required time some technical deb was accumulated and we have to go and implement this flow navigation in a hierarchical way.



The suggestion is to implement a top level activity that is responsible to load a blank screen, with a possible spinner if the operation is too long (see LBLoadingHelper ) This blank activity should start a GridStartupEvaluator and decide where to send the user: {Browse, Login, Subscription, payment, error} This should help flatten the flow of navigation and make it easier to understand and maintain.
Synopsis: Technical debt / request for refactoring - Grid Payment activity should be started from the the top of the stack.

Description: GP10x has split the FE upper pipe into FE0 and FE1. Registers specific to one version of the pipe or the other were duplicated in the ref manual. The historical version of each register is associated with FE0; the new version is associated with FE1. The original naming scheme for the FE1 registers is as follows: NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD_DATA_LOW1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD_DATA_HIGH1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_METHOD_STATE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD31 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_DECODE_METHOD21 Recently it was agreed that the naming convention wasn't great, so the following changes are proposed: NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD_FE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD_DATA_LOW_FE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD_DATA_HIGH_FE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_METHOD_STATE_FE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_CURRENT_METHOD3_FE1 NV_PGRAPH_PRI_FE_DECODE_METHOD2_FE1 The names will change, but the register addresses will not change . Feiqi, please review this list of names and let me know if I forgot any. I will make the all the changes. ARB Feiqi to supply a mainline tree and a vnc for me to work in. After making the changes I will review the fmodel changes with you, or if things are unexpectedly tricky, I'll call you in for help. Feel free to re-ARB.
Synopsis: Rename some of the FE1 PRI registers to have clearer names

Description:
Vulcan does not allow to pass additional Command Line Arguments to Make Commands.
For Ex: We need to override default DRIVER_ROOT or NV_TOOLS that is being set in Makefiles, based on where you want to point your NVCONFIG to or TOOLS to.
Lets say when I am building r7.5 with rel-23 branch in GIT or r7.5 with r355_00, vulcan does not allow me to do that as I cannot pass an additional argument DRIVER_ROOT=<location of rel-23/r355_00>
But I could do that when I am using plain make command
Synopsis: Vulcan does not allow to pass additional Command line arguments to Make Commands

Description:
There is a metric for GPU TOT breaks:



http://gpuwa/nvmetrics/projects/GPU/AS2/bugs/GPU_AS2_Dashboard_TOTBreaksByCause3_SB?period=9months&granularity=days&renderType=highcharts

We need to add a metric similar to that for nvmobile.



It needs to go in the mobile dashboard at http://gpuwa/nvmetrics/mobile/dashboard



Right now the mobile dashboard has the GPU TOT break metric as a placeholder, but it is misleading (and wrong).

Someone might see it and think that it is showing nvmobile TOT breaks.



Starting ARB with Chloe.
Synopsis: [NVMOBILE AS2 METRICS] Add a metric for nvmobile TOT breaks
